Issues.Title: src folder missing in node_modules\@angular\animations
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/animations ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: `@angular/animations@8.0.0-beta.4` ### Description The `src` folder is missing from the `node_modules\@angular\animations` path, so it is not able to access to the `animation_metadata` Typescript file to get the exported members. This started happening since the `@angular/animations@8.0.0-beta.5` version. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Error in console ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR in node_modules/@ngx-gallery/lightbox/lib/lightbox.animation.d.ts(1,48): error TS2307: Cannot find module '@angular/animations/src/animation_metadata'.

Issues.Body:

- [ ] Build related changes

- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes

## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->
Currently, `_reflectModuleFromLiteralType` can only detect `ngModule` from functions that have the return signature of intersect types. This cause compilation error for functions that return a literal object. For example, in `in-memory-web-api`:

https://github.com/angular/in-memory-web-api/blob/b71d39fd48cf189c831603e3ae8fd954216ce2ef/src/in-mem/http-client-in-memory-web-api.module.ts#L43-L52

Or in `@angular/fire`:

https://github.com/angular/angularfire2/blob/b91cd5a84c04628858e09ff19738e5797bd3f88c/src/core/firebase.app.module.ts#L62-L68

Issue Number: #28603


## What is the new behavior?
This PR enables `ngtsc` to recognize such functions.

- [ ] Yes

Issues.Title: feat(core): EventEmitter#subscribe() should be properly typed
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/core

### Description
Currently, subscribing to an `EventEmitter` (via `EventEmitter#subscribe()`) stripes the EventEmitter's type information and [converts it to `any`](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/7.2.7/packages/core/src/event_emitter.ts#L102). This is undesirable, as already pointed out in #6934.

That issue was closed with a nondescript explanation that ~ "you shouldn't use the EventEmitter's `subscribe()` method". However, `EventEmitter#subscribe()` is not marked as internal API.

The suggestion that someone should create a duplicate property, using an rxjs subject, *solely for the purpose of improved typing*, is unsatisfactory.

This is a request to do whatever needs to be done to allow subscribing to `EventEmitter` directly while preserving type information.

### Describe the solution you'd like
The type information, which is already present on `EventEmitter`, should be retained.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Currently, the suggested workaround seems to be to create a duplicate property and update both the `@Output()` property and the duplicate `Subject` property whenever the associated data changes.

e.g.

```
class MyComponent {
  @Input() name: string;
  
  @Output()
  nameChange = new EventEmitter<string>();
  nameChange2 = new Subject<string>();

  @Input() weather: {prediction: string};
  
  @Output()
  weatherChange = new EventEmitter<{prediction: string}>();
  weatherChange2 = new Subject<{prediction: string}>();

  private updateName(name: string) {
    this.name = name;
    this.nameChange.emit(name);
    this.nameChange2.next(name);
  }

  private weatherName(value: {prediction: string}) {
    this.weather = value;
    this.weatherChange.emit(value)
    this.weatherChange2.next(value)
  }
}
``
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(core): EventEmitter#subscribe() should be properly typed" (#29016)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure static styling is properly inherited into child components
Issues.Body:
Angular supports having a component extend off of a parent component.
When this happens, all annotation-level data is inherited including styles
and classes. Up until now, Ivy only paid attention to static styling
values on the parent component and not the child component. This patch
ensures that both the parent's component and child component's styling
data is merged and rendered accordingly.

Jira Issue: FW-1081
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): ensure static styling is properly inherited into child components" (#29015)

Issues.Title: DebugElement Query By.directive returning the wrong directive when a component has same selector
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/core -> DebugElement ### Is this a regression? I'm not sure. ### Description If you have a component and a directive with the same selector, using `debugElement.query(By.directive())` will always return the component and not the directive. This appears to be due to that DebugElement collects based on elements, so the component is registered with DebugElement but if there is a directive with the same selector it is lost. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-1dxvad?file=src%2Fapp%2Fdashboard%2Fdashboard-overloaded.directive.spec.ts If you view this reproduction, you'll see a test running. There are two directives, the DashboardComponent and DashboardOverloadedDirective (it does nothing except console.log). You can see both get instantiated in the test component because they share the same `app-dashboard` selector. Now, when I write a test to query the debugElement by the two directives, both queries return the DashboardComponent instead of the actual directive. The test is below from the stackblitz demo. ```ts it('should query for the directives separately', function() { const component = fixture.debugElement.query(By.directive(DashboardComponent)); const overloaded = fixture.debugElement.query(By.directive(DashboardOverloadedDirective)); expect(component.componentInstance.constructor.name).not.toEqual(overloaded.componentInstance.constructor.name); }) ``` I would expect that `debugElement.query(By.directive(DashboardOverloadedDirective))` would return an instance of the DashboardOverloadedDirective and not the DashboardComponent. With some debugging I see that the test only creates a debugElement for the DashboardComponent (set a breakpoint on https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/core/src/debug/debug_node.ts#L44), which makes sense in some ways because its one element. However, I have no way to access the controller for the directive on that element. ## üî• Exception or Error The error is that both queries above resolve to the same DashboardComponent. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 7.0.3
Node: 10.12.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 7.0.0
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... http, language-service, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server, router

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.10.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.10.3
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.10.3
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer    0.10.3
@angular-devkit/build-webpack      0.10.3
@angular-devkit/core               7.0.3
@angular-devkit/schematics         7.0.3
@angular/cli                       7.0.3
@ngtools/json-schema               1.1.0
@ngtools/webpack                   7.0.3
@schematics/angular                7.0.3
@schematics/update                 0.10.3
ng-packagr                         4.3.0
rxjs                               6.3.3
typescript                         3.1.3
webpack                            4.19.1
**Anything else relevant?** The workaround is to grab the directive `fixture.debugElement.query(By.directive(DashboardComponent)).injector.get(DashboardOverloadedDirective)` but is not obvious.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DebugElement Query By.directive returning the wrong directive when a component has same selector" (#29014)

Issues.Title: Cookie not set in browser from HTTPS response
Issues.Body:
Cookie set in browser automatically at client side if client and server on same domain for example **https:example.com** and not set cookie if client and server is on different domain like client is on domain https://sub1.example1.com and server is on domain https://sub2.example2.com

Please refer following link for more details: 
[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54898549/cookie-not-set-in-browser-from-https-response](url)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cookie not set in browser from HTTPS response" (#29001)

Issues.Title: [Feature Request] Logical / Virtual Modules
Issues.Body:
### Relevant Package

Angular/core

Suppose we have a component that we want to publish on NPM and all it does is say hello.  I think the DRYest way to do this is just publish the component with one core component file.

So where is the module?  The module would be implied and created at runtime for the component.  Now if we specifically wanted to include / assign the component to a module it could be done in the annotation:

```
@component(moduleId: '@angular/material/extension')
```

[This could be complementary to this](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/28826) in the sense that now neither `entryComponents` or `declarations` are necessary as components always have an understanding of what module they belong to since it either has to be annotated on the component or in the module.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Feature Request] Logical / Virtual Modules" (#29007)

Issues.Title: Clarification needed regarding how to load routing config using .forRoot()
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description
on page describing @NgModule it is mentioned that :
Only call and import a .forRoot() result in the root application module, AppModule. Importing it in any other module, particularly in a lazy-loaded module, is contrary to the intent and will likely produce a runtime error. For more information, see Singleton Services.
which is not exactly true where its possible to use forRoot() to be used in a seperate module and import that module into root module 

However it is possible to load Routing config using forRoot() in a seperate routing module 
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> A clear and concise description of the problem...
As shown below in minimal reproduction code section and as  is followed by many teams including ours without any problems. So some clarification is needed regarding the part where it is mentioned that **forRoot() is not intended** to be used in **any other module than root module or app module**.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**
https://angular.io/guide/ngmodule-faq

### Reproduction Steps**
import { NgModule } from '@angular/core';
import { RouterModule, Routes } from '@angular/router';

import { LoginComponent } from './user/login/login.component'; //your component

const routes: Routes = [
    { path: 'login', component: LoginComponent}
  ];

@NgModule({
  imports: [ RouterModule.forRoot(routes) ],
  exports: [
      RouterModule
   ] 
})
export class RoutingModule { };

import { RoutingModule } from './routing.module';

@NgModule({
  declarations: [],
  imports: [
    RoutingModule
  ],
  exports: [],
  providers: [],
  bootstrap: [AppComponent]
})
export class AppModule {}

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**
Expected : There should be problems or run time errors as forRoot() is used in Routing module and not in app ,odule/root module even though indirectly probably at run time is is loaded in app module?

Actual Behavior:
there is no such run time error when loaded in a separate module other than app module.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clarification needed regarding how to load routing config using .forRoot()" (#29002)

Issues.Title: What does Storage service mean ?
Issues.Body:
In storage.service.ts file, we see that InjectionToken<Storage>
and also in the constructor a dependency is added with type as Storage 
constructor(@Inject(BROWSER_STORAGE) public storage: Storage) {}

where is this Storage coming from ? there is no import for this.

Issues.Title: fix(forms): remove deprecated support for ngModel on reactive form directives
Issues.Body:
BREAKING CHANGE:

In v6, we deprecated support for the ngModel and ngModelChange inputs on
reactive form directives. We are now removing these deprecated APIs for
v8.  See the original change here for more info on why:
https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/22633.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(forms): remove deprecated support for ngModel on reactive form directives" (#28996)

Closes #24291

Issues.Title: ng_package may generate imports to external packages bypassing the globals config
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package `@angular/bazel` ### Description `@Injectable`s compiled using `ng_package` may contain generated imports referencing external libraries. Normally external libraries would be put in the `ng_package` `globals` so they are not included in the package, but the generated imports might unexpectedly reference sub-paths of those libraries not listed in `globals`. This could a) cause external things to be included in the package b) cause a compilation error if any components are referenced by those generated imports because the `ngfactory` files are excluded (see below or repro) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/jbedard/ng_package-material, specifically https://github.com/jbedard/ng_package-material/commit/6dbe9da746f463a8e519272c5d4e8c2a9e8dba99 ## üî• Exception or Error ``` [!] (Plugin at position 3 plugin) Error: Could not resolve import '@angular/cdk/scrolling/virtual-scroll-viewport.ngfactory' from '...long tmp dir path.../bazel-out/darwin-fastbuild/bin//npm.es6/external/angular_material/src/cdk/overlay/overlay-container.js' ``` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
7.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ng_package may generate imports to external packages bypassing the globals config" (#28991)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): change layout of e2e files
Issues.Body:
With this change E2E files will be relocated inside an existing application instead of creating a seperate E2E project. This will also remove a lot of extra boilerplating inside the workspace configuration file.

File layout:
```
‚îÇ   browserslist
‚îÇ   karma.conf.js
‚îÇ   tsconfig.app.json
‚îÇ   tsconfig.spec.json
‚îÇ   tslint.json
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄe2e
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   protractor.conf.js
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   tsconfig.e2e.json
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄsrc
‚îÇ           app.e2e-spec.ts
‚îÇ           app.po.ts
‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄsrc
    ‚îÇ   favicon.ico
    ‚îÇ   index.html
    ‚îÇ   main.po.ts
    ‚îÇ   main.ts
    ‚îÇ   polyfills.ts
    ‚îÇ   styles.css
    ‚îÇ   test.ts
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄapp
    ‚îÇ       app.component.css
    ‚îÇ       app.component.html
    ‚îÇ       app.component.spec.ts
    ‚îÇ       app.component.ts
    ‚îÇ       app.module.ts
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄassets
    ‚îÇ       .gitkeep
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄenvironments
            environment.prod.ts
            environment.ts
```

Ref: TOOL-699

Issues.Title: Cannot install @angular/cli from Nexus
Issues.Body:
Because of this issue https://github.com/zkat/protoduck/issues/6 (protoduck is a dependency of pacote), @angular/cli cannot be installed anymore from the Nexus NPM Proxy.

I decided to raise attention to this issue to Angular team because I think the fix could be quicker if you take care of it (and it is a total blocker for my company).

Issues.Title: Ionic - Module parse failed: Unexpected token (6:2160)
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [X] build ### Is this a regression? Yes kind of ### Description I, we, are upgrading our application's Angular and Cordova-ios versions and while doing so, if we remove the `package-lock.json` and fetch all the libraries newly, are facing the following an error when we run afterwards our application doing `ionic serve`: ``` [ng] ERROR in ./node_modules/@ionic/core/dist/esm/es5/ionic.core.js 6:2160 [ng] Module parse failed: Unexpected token (6:2160) ``` I say we as the problem has been reported on the Ionic forum https://forum.ionicframework.com/t/incompatibility-to-cordova-ios-5-0-0 and Ionic GitHub https://github.com/ionic-team/ionic/issues/17605 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` git clone https://github.com/peterpeterparker/dependencies cd dependencies npm install ionic serve ``` Note: if you don't face the error doing the above list of commands, then delete the `package-lock.json` and fetch the libraries again ``` rm -r package-lock.json rm -r node_modules npm install ionic serve ``` ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Disable start-up warnings
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [X] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

My application has a couple of settings that are perfectly secure within the context of their use, but which produce (certainly helpful) warnings.  I've configured my app this way intentionally, and I don't want to see these warnings every time I start my application for development.

Here is my command:

    ng serve --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000 --ssl true --ssl-key localhost.key --ssl-cert localhost.cert

And the warnings:

```
WARNING: This is a simple server for use in testing or debugging Angular applications
locally. It hasn't been reviewed for security issues.

Binding this server to an open connection can result in compromising your application or
computer. Using a different host than the one passed to the "--host" flag might result in
websocket connection issues. You might need to use "--disableHostCheck" if that's the
case.
```

The top one is useful, but I don't need to be reminded, I'm already not using Angular CLI in production.

The second one is of course useful as well, but I'm running this app inside of a Docker container on my dev machine with an port exposed to the host, so that's not an issue in my case either.

### Describe the solution you'd like
A broad flag (or a number of more specific flags) to disable warnings at start time.  I have found another issue requesting something like this here:

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/11802

However, the answer given to this is to redirect stderr.  This does have the desired effect, but it _also_ disables all compile-time errors, which I _need_ for the development process.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Either find a configuration that Angular complains about less, or simply ignore the warnings.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Disable start-up warnings" (#13765)

Issues.Title: ng new my-app does not have css per QuickStart Guide
Issues.Body:
Following the new app tutorial https://angular.io/guide/quickstart

Haven't used Angular since Version 4.

When you create a new application exactly per the instructions, there is NO CSS AT ALL.  When you start the development server, no CSS file is even loaded or compiled.

CSS is an absolute must-have for any web application in 2019.  This is a critical issue.  Should we just use react?

To be clear, there is an app.component.scss file but nothing you place in it is used or compiled.

I think it's absolutely reasonable that a new application has working CSS.  It really sets the bar low for the current status of this project.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ng new my-app does not have css per QuickStart Guide" (#13757)

Issues.Title: CdkDropListGroupDisabled Blocking Native Interactions
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?

That `cdkDropListGroupDisabled` directive disabled all the `cdkDrag` components but kept the scrolling behaviour.

#### What is the current behavior?

Native Input not working when using `cdkDropListGroupDisabled`. The disabled effect works, because you can't drag any cdkDrag component. 

Looking at the source code I found that this happened in this function:
https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/740a2eeaa921c201c21b7a0fee980cf05ad7c2aa/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts#L965-L976

Which will call this function:

https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/740a2eeaa921c201c21b7a0fee980cf05ad7c2aa/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-styling.ts#L47-L59

It adds to the style of the component `touch-action: none` when the enabled parameter is false.

Then I looked why it passed false when the disabled variable should be true.

https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/740a2eeaa921c201c21b7a0fee980cf05ad7c2aa/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts#L216-L223

This should get called when disabled and it actually isn't (I placed a breakpoint there).

Then I tested using `cdkDragDisabled` insted of `cdkDropListGroupDisabled` and the setter disable was called and everything worked correctly.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

Create a `cdkDropListGroup` and disable it.


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

Angular Material 7.3.3, Angular CDK 7.3.3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CdkDropListGroupDisabled Blocking Native Interactions" (#15319)

Issues.Title: Header is scrolled when sidenav is opened in "over" mode on iOS devices
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Window should not be scrolled and header should remain visible when sidenav is opened on iOS devices

#### What is the current behavior?
When mat-sidenav is opened in "over" mode and mat-sidenav-content takes the full height of the screen, page is scrolled after a delay and header is scrolled out of the view so it becomes not visible.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material2-issue-wdzkw1?file=app%2Fapp.component.html

GIF shows the issue - initially header is visible, when toggle button is clicked, sidenav opens and then after a small delay header is scrolled out of the view
![sidenav issue on ios](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8079600/53425851-b8a6b700-39dd-11e9-9faf-2b2206544992.gif)


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Stackblitz is using Angular 7.0.1, Material 7.0.2 (the same happens with version 7.2.1)
Issues affects Safari, Chrome and FF on iOS (checked on iPhone7, X and iPad Pro 11 2018)

#### Is there anything else we should know?
No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Header is scrolled when sidenav is opened in "over" mode on iOS devices" (#15315)

Issues.Title: Console error when using arrow keys in a mat-select with a mat-option without value.
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
When selecting a "no value" or "null value" mat-option with keyboard, no error appears in the console output.

#### What is the current behavior?
When selecting a "no value" or "null value" mat-option with keyboard, an error appears in the console output.

> main.5b2eef94be108354fa6e.js:1 ERROR TypeError: Cannot read property 'viewValue' of undefined

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Error is appearing in angular material documentation web site : 
https://material.angular.io/components/select/overview#getting-and-setting-the-select-value

1. Open browser console
2. Select "Option 1" with mouse
3. Use up arrow key to select the "empty mat-option" (None)
4. Look the console output

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular 7
Material 7.3.1
Tested with Chrome and firefox

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Console error when using arrow keys in a mat-select with a mat-option without value." (#15312)

Issues.Title: refactor(button): use [attr.disabled] host binding in MatButton
Issues.Body:
With ivy, MatAnchor will inherit the host bindings of MatButton. The
`[disabled]` binding would then be an error since HTMLAnchorElement does
not have a `disabled` property. To work around this, we can simply use
the `disabled` attribute instead, which will always be reflected back
into the property when it exists.

Also add a missing `fixture.detectChanges()` to a test.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(button): use [attr.disabled] host binding in MatButton" (#15308)

Issues.Title: Refactor RxJS code to not explicitly set generics
Issues.Body:
There are several instances in material where we are setting the generic type of an RxJS function explicitly in order to get a desired outcome. It would be better to cast instead. (Ideally, you don't have to do either, so what I'm talking about here is when you *must* do something explicit to get the return type to be correct)

For example:

```ts
defer<Foo>(() => someObservable)
```

should be:

```ts
defer(() => someObservable) as Observable<Foo>
```
This is because RxJS changes how generics are ordered for some functions between version 6.3 and 6.4.

It may even be worth testing these changes against updating to 6.4.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Refactor RxJS code to not explicitly set generics" (#15307)

Issues.Title: Create TSLint rule to prevent usage of params for animations
Issues.Body: Create TSLint rule to prevent usage of params for animations.  The intention is for this lint rule to be in place to require us to explicitly state why we want to use the param and ensure we declare the accompanying `const` for the parameter being used.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Create TSLint rule to prevent usage of params for animations " (#15306)
